Award.AwardTitle: Science Communication Skill Building for Undergraduates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
There has been considerable press describing the poor understanding of science held by the general public, and extensive research into the misunderstandings of science held by college students. Attempts to turn science prose into general prose has often failed to hit the mark, and there is a need for science professionals to engage actively in informal communication with the public. Carthage College and the Alda Center for Communicating Science at SUNY-Stonybrook, are partnering with Dartmouth College, Smith College, and the Appalachian Mountain Club (AMC), to create and disseminate tools, methods, and materials that can be utilized by colleges, universities, and informal science education organizations to develop the science communication skills of undergraduate STEM students. The program has been successful in training faculty and graduate students in science communication.

This project will utilize and adapt the existing science communication training programs for graduate students and professional researchers as the basis for creating new tools and training methodologies to prepare undergraduate STEM students in science communication. It is expected that as these students enter the workforce, they will be better at communicating and explaining technical concepts, especially to the lay public, and based on results from the current program will be more likely to pursue careers in science education. The tools and methods developed, when adopted by higher education institutions, will lead to a better-prepared technical workforce, and better understanding of science by the general public. The program will include a study of the effectiveness of the interventions through a longitudinal study of assessment and evaluation data from this effort compared with an expansive five-year data set from prior years of the outreach program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed approaches for training undergraduate students in science communication, a critical need if we are to have a next-generation of graduates who are able to communicate in their careers and with the public. The ultimate goal would be for all undergraduate science students to be excellent science communicators by the time they graduate - and be able to apply those skills in any career they may pursue.

Faculty from four academic institutions (Dartmouth College, Smith College, Carthage College, and Stony Brook University) were trained by staff of the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science. These faculty then developed different implementations that they applied with students on their respective campuses. These included dedicated science communication courses, extra-curricular workshops, activities within Society of Physics Students chapters, and integration of science communication into existing courses (including one on science policy). Students who received the training then participated in the Mountains of Stars (MoS) public science education and outreach program, in partnership with the Appalachian Mountain Club and its education and conservation mission.  The performance of the students was monitored and assessed to determine which of the implementations was effective at preparing them for public engagement. Over the term of the grant, three cohorts of students participated, with the on-campus training updated and adjusted each year based on the evaluation of the prior-year program results. Key outcomes: All of the implementations prepared the students to work with the public relatively equally,  but the greatest gains were seen after they completed their 12 week summer experience in the MoS program. This indicates that on-campus training is effective at providing a good baseline set of communication skills, but that the biggest impact comes from actual, extensive practice with the public. It remains to be seen how that kind of intensive experience can be provided to large cohorts of students, such as at research universities where the student body may number in the hundreds to thousands.

During this project, the evaluation process was based on twenty students who participated in MoS as astronomy and nature education guides (drawn from a pool of more than 100 who received on-campus science communication education). Some 30,700 members of the public participated in the program, giving the students excellent opportunities to interact with diverse audiences of varying ages, backgrounds, and socioeconomic status.  Students who participated showed increased interest in pursuing public science education as part of their careers, including several who chose to go into education graduate programs as a result of their participation. Several others took positions with other outdoor/public education organizations (such as the National Park Service). Thus, we also see how the experience of doing extensive public education motivates students to further study and participation in science communication careers.
